description: Resurfacing works to the existing inner trackways within the Southern (Explorer) Car Park
decision_conditions: The proposed resurfacing works are considered to fall within the parameters of  permitted development as set out under Schedule 2, Part 9, Class E of the Town and Country Planning (General Permitted Development) (England) Order 2015 (as amended).

Officer ReportApplication SiteThe site comprises a semi detached dwelling. The site is not subject to any particular designations or environmental constraints.Proposal Demolition of existing rear conservatory and erection of single storey rear extension.Consultations7 properties were notified of the proposal. No representations were received.  The key areas of assessment are:- The design of the proposed development; and,- The impact of the development on the amenities of existing and future occupants of land and buildings; and,- Fire SafetyCharacter and AppearanceWhen read together Policies CS8 and DM10 of the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Local Development Framework Core Strategy (CS)(2012) and the guidance in the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Residential Design Guide SPD (2013) require proposals to be of a high quality design that respects the character and appearance of the original building and the prevailing character of the surrounding area. Officer Comment: The proposed extension would be approximately 3.5m deep and it would replace the existing 4m deep conservatory. It is acknowledged that the proposed single storey rear extension would not be strictly in accordance with Policy Guidance 33 of the Council's Residential Design SPD with regards to the recommended depth as it would join the existing rear extension and would result in total depth of approximately 5.7m. However, considering its siting and the proposed design as well as the existing extension at the adjoining property No 7 Manor Close, it is considered that the proposal would be in-keeping with the host dwelling and the surrounding area. Neighbouring AmenitiesPolicy DM10 of the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Local Development Framework Core Strategy (CS)(2012) and the guidance in the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Residential Design Guide SPD (2013) requires proposal to have regard to the amenities of the future occupants of the development as well as those of the existing occupants of neighbouring land and buildings, including in terms of privacy, outlook, sunlight/daylight, avoidance of visual intrusion and noise and disturbance.Officer Comment: It is considered that the proposed development due to its siting and modest scale would not adversely affect the amenities of the occupiers of neighbouring properties by reason of overbearing appearance, loss of light or loss of privacy. The proposal would pass the 45 degree rule in relation to both adjoining properties and therefore it would not result in an unacceptable loss of daylight in relation to these neighbouring properties. Fire SafetyLondon Plan Policy D12(A) requires all development proposals to achieve the highest standards of fire safety, embedding these at the earliest possible stage.The applicant has not submitted a Fire Safety Strategy, however, the plans include the provision of a suitably positioned outside space for fire appliances/ an evacuation assembly point and officers see no reason why a development of the type sought could not comply with the rest of the provisions of Policy D12(A), the details of which could be secured through conditions. For these reasons, officers conclude that the proposal would not conflict with Policy D12 of the London Plan.ConclusionIn conclusion, the proposed development is considered to be  in accordance with the development plan taken as a whole and there are no other material considerations which warrant a decision other than in accordance with the development plan.
